questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which one of the following aspects is in exclusive characteristics of living things?

options.content: Increase in mass from inside only
Perception of events happening in the environment and their memory.
Increase in mass by accumulation  of material both on surface as well as internally.

questions.explanation:
All living things have an ability to
respond to their environment, that is also
called stimulation.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: The pathogen Microsporum responsible for ringworm disease in humans belongs to the same kingdom of organisms as that of
questions.explanation:
Microsporum is a member of Deuteromycetes of fungi & Rhizopus is also fungi and
member of Zygomycetes.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Selaginella and Salvinia are considered to represent a significant step toward evolution of seed habit because

options.content: female gametophyte is free and gets dispersed like seeds.
megaspores possess endosperm and embryo surrounded by seed coat.
embryo develops in female gametophyte which is retained on parent sporophyte.

questions.explanation:
Selaginella and Salvinia are advanced
pteridophytes.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Consider the following four statements whether they are correct or wrong.
A.   The sporophyte in liverworts is more eleborate than that in mosses.
B.    Salvinia is heterosporous.
C.   The life-cycle in all seed-bearing plants is diplontic.
D.   In Pinus male and female cones are borne on different trees.

The two wrong statements together are
questions.explanation: The sporophyte in mosses is more elaborate than that in liverworts. The male and female cones or strobili is borne on same tree in (Pinus). In Cycas male cones and megasporophylls are borne on different trees.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Ureters act as urinogenital ducts in
questions.explanation:
In male frogs, two ureters act as urinogenital
duct which open into the cloaca. They run backwards
from the kidneys and open into the cloaca. In female
ureters carry urine alone, while in male both sperms
and urine are carried. Hence, are called urinogenital
ducts.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Consider the following four statements (A$$-$$D) related to the common frog Rana tigrina, and select the correct option starting which ones are true (T) and which ones are false (F). Statements:
A.  On dry land it would die due to lack of O2 if its mouth is forcibly kept closed for a few days.
B.  It has four-chambered heart.
C.  On dry land it turns uricotelic from ureotelic.
D.  Its life-history is carried out in pond water.
questions.explanation:
(A) Dry skin causes ceased cutaneous respiration
(B) Three chambered heart.
(C) Frog never becomes uricotelic
(D) External fertilization occurs in water

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which one of the following statements is totally wrong about the occurrence of notochord, while the other three are correct?

options.content: It is present only in larval tail in ascidian.
It is replaced by a vertebral column in adult frog.
It is absent throughout life in humans form the very beginning.
It is present throughout life in Amphioxus.

questions.explanation:
Notochord is present is the embryonic stage
which is replaced by bony vertebral column.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Whorled, simple leaves with reticulate venation are present in
questions.explanation:
Whorled phyllotaxy is a feature of
Nerium and Alstonia. In Alstonia five leaves
are present in a whorl while in Nerium three
leaves are present in a whorl.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Sweet potato is homologous to
questions.explanation:
Sweet potato is homologous to turnip as
both are having same origin i.e., both are root but
modified for different functions. Sweet potato is a
modified root for storage and vegetative propagation
while turnip is modified for storage only.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which one of the following pairs is wrongly matched while the remaining three are correct?
questions.explanation:
Water hyacinth is a free floating perennial
plant, which can grow to a height of 3 feet.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: At metaphase, chromosomes are attached to the spindle fibres by their
questions.explanation:
Kinetochores are large protein
complexes that bind the centromeres of
chromosomes to the microtubules of mitotic
spindle fibres, during metaphase in the cell
cycle.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In kranz anatomy, the bundle sheath cells have

options.content: thin walls, may intercellular spaces and no chloroplasts
thick walls, no intercellular spaces and large number of chloroplasts
thin walls, no intercellular spaces and several chloroplasts
thick walls, many intercellular spaces and few chloroplasts.

questions.explanation:
In Kranz anatomy, the bundle sheath
cells have thick wall, no intracellular spaces
and large number of chloroplasts.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In mitochondria, protons accumulate in the
questions.explanation:
In respiration, protons accumulate in the
intermembrane space of the mitochondria when
electrons move through the ETS.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which one of the following is a possibility for most of us in regard to breathing, by making a conscious effort?

options.content: One can breathe out air totally without oxygen.
One can breathe out air through Eustachian tube by closing both nose and mouth.
One can consciously breathe in and breathe out by moving the diaphragm alone, without moving the ribs at all.
The lungs can be made fully empty by forcefully breathing out all air from them.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct because the diaphragm is the main muscle responsible for breathing, and it separates the chest cavity from the abdominal cavity. By making a conscious effort, one can control the movement of the diaphragm and breathe in and out without moving the ribs at all. This is called diaphragmatic breathing or belly breathing. It is a technique often used in yoga, meditation, and other relaxation exercises to increase oxygenation and reduce stress. With practice, diaphragmatic breathing can become a natural and automatic way of breathing, even during regular activities.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Bulk of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) released from body tissues into the blood is present as

options.content: bicarbonate in blood plasma and RBCs

questions.explanation:
70% to 75% CO<sub>2</sub> is transported as
primary buffer of the blood bicarbonate ion
(HCO<sub>3</sub>) in blood plasma. When CO<sub>2</sub> diffuses
from tissues into blood then it is acted upon
by the enzyme carbonic anhydrase.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Given below is the ECG of a normal human. Which one of its components is correctly interpreted below?

options.content: Peak T - initiation of total cardiac contraction
Peak P and peak R together - systolic and diastolic blood pressures
Peak P- initiation of left atrial contraction only

questions.explanation:
By counting the number of QRS complexes
that occur in a given time period, one can determine
the heart beat rate (pulse) of an individual. The QRS
complex represents the depolarisation of the
ventricles, which initiates the ventricular contraction.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Uricotelic mode of excreting nitrogenous wastes is found in
questions.explanation:
Reptiles, birds, land snails and insects
excrete nitrogenous wastes as uric acid in the form of
pellet or paste with a minimum loss of water and are
called uricotelic animals.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: The type of muscles present in our

options.content: heart is involuntary and unstriated smooth muscles
upper arm is smooth muscle and fusiform in shape.

questions.explanation:
Cardiac muscles are found in the wall of
the heart. It is involuntary and slightly striated.
Smooth muscles are found in gastrointestinal tract.
These are non-striated and involuntary. Striated (or
skeletal) muscles are found in the limbs and body
walls. These muscles are voluntary (under the control
of animals’ will) and show dark and light bands thus
are striated.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: The 24 hour (diurnal) rhythm of our body such as the sleep-wake cycle is regulated by the hormone
questions.explanation:
Melatonin is a hormone that regulates
the 24 hour rhythm of our body such as the
sleep-wake cycle etc. Melatonin is produced
by pineal gland in the brain, which is
responsible for operation and regulation of
the biological clock in mammals.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: In angiosperms, functional megaspore develops into
questions.explanation:
During megagametogenesis functional
megaspore (mostly chalazal) gives rise
to embryo sac. This is the mature female
gametophyte generation.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: What is common between vegetative reproduction and apomixts?

options.content: Both are applicable to only dicot plants
Both produced progeny identical to the parent.

questions.explanation:
Apomixis is a reproductive process in
plants that superficially resembles normal sexual
reproduction but in which there is no fusion of
gametes. The embryos develop simply by division
of a diploid cell the ovule. So, the progenies
produced are identical to the parent. In vegetative
reproduction the progenies produced are also
identical to the parent.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
About which day in a normal human menstrual
cycle does rapid secretion of LH (popularly
called LH-surge) normally occurs?
questions.explanation:
At 14<sup>th</sup> day of normal human menstrual
cycle rapid secretion of LH normally occurs.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
What happens during fertilization in humans
after many sperms reach close to the ovum?

options.content:
Only two sperms nearest the ovum
penetrate zona pellucida

Secretions of acrosome helps one sperm
enter cytoplasm of ovum through zona
pellucida

All sperms except the one nearest to the
ovum lose their tails

Cells of corona radiate trap all the sperms
except one.

questions.explanation:
The process of fusion of a sperm with an
ovum is called fertilization. During fertilization, a
sperm comes in contact with the zona pellucida layer
of the ovum and induces changes in the membrane
that block the entry of additional sperms. Thus, it
ensures that only one sperm can fertilize an ovum.
The secretions of the acrosome help the sperm enter
into the cytoplasm of the ovum through the zona
pellucida and the plasma membrane. In contact with
the surface of egg covering, the acrosome releases its
contained hydrolytic enzymes, also called sperm
lysins. It is known as acrosomal reaction. Acrosome
reaction results in dissolving of corona cells and
degeneration of zona pellucida which helps in sperm
penetration.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
The technique called gamete intrafallopian
transfer (GIFT) is recommended for those
females :

options.content: who cannot retain the foetus inside uterus

who cannot provide suitable environment
for fertilisation

whose cervical canal is too narrow to allow
passage for the sperms

questions.explanation:
Gamete Intra Fallopian Transfer (GIFT) is
transfer of an ovum collected from a donor into the
Fallopian tube of another female who cannot produce
ova but can provide proper environment for
fertilization and further development.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following conditions of the
zygotic cell would lead to the birth of a normal
human female child ?

options.content: one X and one Y chromosome

questions.explanation:
Two X chromosomes would lead to the
birth of normal human female child.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Test cross in plants or in Drosophila involves
crossing :

options.content: the F<sub>1</sub> hybrid with a double recessive genotype
between two genotypes with dominant trait
between two genotypes with recessive trait

questions.explanation:
In test cross, genotype of an organism
showing dominant phenotype is determined
by crossing it with homozygous recessive
genotype.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
The unequivocal proof of DNA as the genetic
material came from the studies on a :
questions.explanation:
The unequivocal proof that DNA is the
genetic material came from the experiments of Alfred
Hershey and Martha Chase (1952). They worked with
viruses that infect bacteria called bacteriophages.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following options gives the
correct matching of a disease with its causative
organism and mode of infection ?

options.content: Disease $$ \to $$ Pneumonia, Causative Organisms $$ \to $$ Streptococcus pneumoniae, Mode of Infection $$ \to $$ Droplet infection
Disease $$ \to $$ Malaria, Causative Organisms $$ \to $$ Plasmodium vivax, Mode of Infection $$ \to $$ Bite of male Anopheles mosquito
Disease $$ \to $$ Elephantiasis , Causative Organisms $$ \to $$ Wuchereria bancrofti, Mode of Infection $$ \to $$ With infected water and food
Disease $$ \to $$ Typhoid , Causative Organisms $$ \to $$ Salmonella typhi, Mode of Infection $$ \to $$ With inspired air

questions.explanation:
Pneumonia disease is spread by the
organism Streptococcus pneumoniae and the
mode of infection is by droplet infection.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Common cold is not cured by antibiotics
because it is :
questions.explanation:
Common cold is due to rhinovirus.
Recent studies found that antibiotics do not
kill this virus.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Read the following statement having two blanks (A and B) :
''A drug used for ______ (A)___ patients is obtained from a species of the organism ______ (B)___ ''.
The one correct option for the two blanks is :
questions.explanation:
Trichoderma is a species of filamentous
fungi. Cyclosporin A is immunosuppressive
drug obtained from Trichoderma and used in
organ transplantation.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following is a wrong matching
of a microbe and its industrial product, while the
remaining three are correct ?:
questions.explanation:
Microbes are used for commercial and
industrial production of certain chemicals like organic
acids, alcohols and enzymes. Examples of acid
producers are Aspergillus niger (a fungus) of citric
acid, Acetobacter aceti (a bacterium) of acetic acid;
Clostridium butylicum (a bacterium) of butyric acid
and Lactobacillus (a bacterium) of lactic acid.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Consider the following statements (A-D) about organic farming :
(A) Utilizes genetically modified crops like Bt cotton
(B) Uses only naturally produced inputs like compost
(C) Does not use pesticides and urea
(D) Produces vegetables rich in vitamins and minerals
Which of the above statements are correct ?
questions.explanation:
Organic farming is the form of agriculture
that relies on the techniques like crop rotation,
green manure, compost and biological pest
control.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following techniques made it
possible to genetically engineer living organisms ?
questions.explanation:
Recombinant DNA technology is the
process joining together two DNA molecules
from two different species that are inserted
into a host organism to produce new genetic
combination.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Bacillus thuringiensis forms protein crystals
which contain insecticidal protein. This protein :

options.content:
is activated by acid pH of the foregut of the
insect pest.

binds with epithelial cells of midgut of the
insect pest ultimately killing it

is coded by several genes including the gene
cry

does not kill the carrier bacterium which is
itself resistant to this toxin

questions.explanation:
Bacillus thuringiensis produces a large
amount of crystalline protein during
sporulation. In the cell toxins are formed
along with the spore and are referred to as
parasporal body. The bacteria are capable
of entering the insect’s blood and using the
host insect to reproduce. The proteins from
ingested spores are activated by gut, high
pH and the polypeptide toxins destroy gut
epithelial cells and kill the pest.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Silencing of mRNA has been used in producing
transgenic plants resistant to :
questions.explanation:
In this technique nematode specific genes
are introduced in the host plant in such a way
that it produces both sense and antisense
RNA. The two RNA’s being complementary
to each other from a double stranded RNA
(dsRNA) which is also called interfering RNA
responsible for initiating RNA interference
(RNA i). This (dsRNA) bind to and prevent
translation of specific mRNA of nematode
(gene silencing). Thus transgenic plants
based on RNAi technology are resistant to
nematode.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Read the following four statements (A-D) about certain mistakes in two of them :
(A) The first transgenic buffalo, Rosie produced milk which was human alpha-lactalbumin enriched.
(B) Restriction enzymes are used in isolation of DNA from other macro-molecules
(C) Downstream processing is one of the steps of R-DNA technology
(D) Disarmed pathogen vectors are also used in transfer of R-DNA into the host
Which are the two statements having mistakes ?
questions.explanation:
In 1997, the first transgenic cow, Rosie,
produced human protein enriched milk. The milk
contained the human alpha-lactalbumin and was
nutritionally a more balanced product for human
babies than natural cow-milk. Isolation of DNA from
other macromolecule is achieved by treating the
bacterial cells/plant or animal tissue with enzymes
such as lysozyme (bacteria), cellulase (plant cells),
chitinase (fungus).

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
The logistic population growth is expressed by
the equation :
questions.explanation:
The logistic population growth is 
expressed by the equation $${{dN} \over {dt}} = rN\left( {{{\left( {K - N} \right)} \over K}} \right)$$
where N is population density at time t, r is
the Malthusian parameter (rate of maximum
population growth) and K is the so called
carrying capacity (i.e. maximum sustainable 
population). It is a type of population growth
when resources are limiting.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following animals may occupy
more than one trophic levels in the same
ecosystem at the same time ?
questions.explanation:
Sparrow can be herbivorous (eating seeds
and fruits) or carnivorous (eating insects).

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Both, hydrarch and xerarch successions lead to :
questions.explanation:
Hydrarch succession takes place in wetter
areas and the successional series progress from
hydric to the mesic condition . Xerarch succession
takes place in dry areas and the series progress
from xeric to mesic condition. Hence, both hydrarch 
and xerarch succession leads to medium water
conditions (mesic).

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
The breakdown of detritus into smaller particles
by earthworm is a process called
questions.explanation:
The break down of detritus into
smaller particles by earthworm is known as
fragmentation.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Consider the following statements (A)-(D) each with one or two blanks :
(A) Bears go into _____ (1) ____ during winter to _____(2)____ cold weather.
(B) A conical age pyramid with a broad base represents ____(3)_____ human population.
(C) A wasp pollinating a fig flower is an example of _____ (4) _____ .
(D) An area with high levels of species richness is known as ____(5)_____.
Which of the following options, gives the correct fill ups for the respective blank numbers from (1) to (5) in the statements ?

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Biodiversity of a geographical region represents :

options.content:
The diversity in the organisms living in the
region

Genetic diversity present in the dominant
species of the region.
Endangered species found in the region

questions.explanation:
Biodiversity is the number of variety of
organism found within a specified geographic
region.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Some vascular bundles are described as open
because these :

options.content:
are capable of producing secondary xylem
and phloem

possess conjunctive tissue between xylem
and phloem

are surrounded by pericycle but no
endodermis

questions.explanation:
In dicot stem, cambium is present between
xylem and phloem, such vascular bundles are called
open. In monocot stem, the cambium is absent, such
vascular bundles are called closed.
Cambium are the meristematic cells which produces
secondary xylem and phloem.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Function of companion cells is :

options.content: Loading of sucrose into sieve elements

Loading of sucrose into sieve elements by
passive transport

Providing energy to sieve elements for active
transport

questions.explanation:
Companion cells move sugar and amino
acids into and out of the sieve elements. In “source”
tissue such as leaf companion cells use
transmembrane proteins to take up sugar and amino
acids by active transport. Movement of sugars in the
phloem begins at the source, where sugars are loaded
(actively transported) into a seive tube. Loading sets
up a water potential gradient that facilitates movement
of sugar.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Frogs differ from humans in possessing :
questions.explanation:
Human possesses enucleated RBCs in
mature state. But frog blood has both white and red blood cells which are nucleated. Frog
cells do not lack platelets.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
The cells lining the blood vessels belongs to the
category of :
questions.explanation:
Simple squamous epithelium is composed
of large flat cells whose edges fit closely together like
the tiles in a floor, hence it is also called pavement
epithelium. The nuclei of the cells are flattened and
often lie at the centre of the cells and cause bulgings
of cells surface. The epithelium lines the blood
vessels, lymph vessels, heart, terminal bronchioles,
alveoli of the lungs, walls of the Bowman’s capsules,
descending limbs of loop of Henle. In the blood
vessels and heart it is called endothelium.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following structure in pheretima
is correctly matched with its function ?
questions.explanation:
Clitellum - secretes cocoon during
breading season of earthworm. Gizzard is
used for- grinding of food particles. Setae
help in locomotion. Typhlosole increases the
absorption area in intestine.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following is not considered as
a part of the endomembrane system ?
questions.explanation:
Except peroxisome the remaining three
and ER are the parts of endomembrane
system.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: The figure below shows the structure of a mitochondrion with its four parts labelled (A), (B), (C). and (D) Select the part correctly matched with its function. –

options.content:
Part (B) : Inner membrane – forms
infoldings called cristae

Part (C) : Cristae – possess single circular
DNA molecule and ribosome

Part (A) : Matrix – major site for
respiratory chain enzymes

Part (D) : Outer membrane – gives rise to
inner membrane by splitting

questions.explanation:
Each mitochondrion is a double membranebound structure with the outer membrane and the inner membrane dividing its lumen distinctly into two aqueous compartments, i.e., the outer compartment and the inner compartment. The inner compartment is called the matrix.

The outer membrane forms the continuous limiting boundary of the organelle. The inner membrane forms a number of infoldings called the cristae towards the matrix. The cristae increase the surface area. The two membranes have their own specific enzymes associated with the mitochondrial function.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Examine the figure given below and select the correct option giving all the four parts (A, B, C and D) rightly identified.
questions.explanation:
The given figure is of female thallus of
Marchantia (bryophyte) in which A, B, C and D are
archegoniophore, female thallus, gemmacup and
rhizoids respectively.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: Which one of the following figures represents the placentation in Dianthus?
questions.explanation:
The figure given in option (d) represents the
free central placentation. In free central placentation,
ovary is unilocular and ovules are borne on the axis
in the center of the ovary and septa are absent. It is
seen in Dianthus and Primrose.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content: The figures (A – D) show four animals. Select the correct option with respect to a common characteristic of two of these animals.

options.content:
(A) and (D) respire mainly through body
wall

questions.explanation:
From annelida to chordata all organisms
are eucoelomate. C-Mollusca (Octopus),
D-Arthropoda (Scorpion) have a true coelom.

questions.subject: biology
questions.content:
Which one of the following is essential for
photolysis of water?
questions.explanation:
Manganese (Mn<sup>2+</sup>) is used for photolysis of
water to produce oxygen and electrons during light
reaction of photosynthesis. It is the phenomenon of
breaking up of water into hydrogen and oxygen in the
illuminated chloroplast. It acts as an essential cofactor.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Which has the maximum number of molecules among the following ?
questions.explanation: 8 g H<sub>2</sub> has 4 moles while the others has 1 mole each.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: According to the Bohr theory, which of the following transitions in the hydrogen atom will give rise to the least energetic photon ?
questions.explanation:
We know that

$$\Delta E \propto \left[ {{1 \over {n_1^2}} - {1 \over {n_2^2}}} \right]$$, where n2 > n1

$$ \therefore $$ n = 6 and n = 5 will give least energetic photon.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: What is the value of electron gain enthalpy of Na<sup>+</sup> if IE<sub>1</sub> of Na = 5.1 eV?
questions.explanation:
Na $$ \to $$ Na+ + e-; $$\Delta $$H = 5.1 eV

Na+ + e- $$ \to $$ Na; $$\Delta $$H = -5.1 eV

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Which of the following structures is the most preferred and hence of lowest energy for SO<sub>3</sub>?
questions.explanation: has maximum number of covalent bonds.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
Consider the following processes :

H (kJ/mol)
1/2A $$ \to $$ B +150
3B  $$ \to $$ 2C + D -125
E + A  $$ \to $$ 2D +350

For B + D $$ \to $$ E + 2C, $$\Delta $$H will be
questions.explanation:
H (kJ/mol)
1/2A $$ \to $$ B +150
3B  $$ \to $$ 2C + D -125
E + A  $$ \to $$ 2D +350
___________________________________
   B + D $$ \to $$ E + 2C;

$$\Delta $$H = (300 - 125 - 350) = - 175 kJ/mol

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
In qualitative analysis, the metals of group I can be separated from other ions by precipitating them as chloride salts. A solution initially contains Ag+ and pb2+ at a concentration of 0.10 M. Aqueous HCl is added to this solution until the Cl$$-$$ concentration is 0.10 M. What will the concentrations of Ag+ and Pb2+ be at equilibrium ?

(Ksp for AgCl = 1.8 $$ \times $$ 10$$-$$10, Ksp for PbCl2 = 1.7 $$ \times $$ 10$$-$$5)
questions.explanation:
Ksp[AgCl] = [Ag+][Cl-]

$$ \Rightarrow $$ [Ag+] = $${{1.8 \times {{10}^{ - 10}}} \over {{{10}^{ - 1}}}}$$ = 1.8 $$ \times $$ 10$$-$$9 M

Ksp[PbCl2] = [Pb2+][Cl-]2

$$ \Rightarrow $$ [Pb2+] = $${{1.7 \times {{10}^{ - 5}}} \over {{{10}^{ - 1}} \times {{10}^{ - 1}}}}$$ = 1.7 $$ \times $$ 10$$-$$3 M

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Which of the following compounds undergoes nucleophilic substitution reaction most easily?
questions.explanation: Electron withdrawing group like -NO<sub>2</sub> facilitates nucleophilic substitution reaction in chlorobenzene.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The IUPAC name of the following compound is
questions.explanation: $$ \therefore $$ IUPAC name is trans-2-chloro-3-iodo-2-pentene.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
Consider the reactions.

The mechanisms of reactions (i) and (ii) are respectively
questions.explanation:
These reactions are purely S<sub>N</sub>2
 reactions as in
reaction (i) and (ii) there is no rearrangement takes
place (rearrangement occurs in S<sub>N</sub>1
 mechanism).
Simple substitution of nucleophile takes place.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
Match the compounds given in List-I with List-II and select the suitable option using the code given below.

List-I
 List-II
(A) Benzaldehyde (i) Phenolphthalein
(B) Phthalic anhydride (ii) Benzoin condensation
(C) Phenyl benzoate (iii) Oil of wintergreen
(D) Methyl salicylate (iv) Fries rearrangement
questions.explanation:
(A) Benzaldehyde          (ii) Benzoin condensation

(B) Phthalic anhydride    (i) Phenolphthalein

(C) Phenyl benzoate       (iv) Fries rearrangement

(D) methyl salicylate      (iii) Oil of wintergreen

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: An organic compound A on treatment with NH<sub>3</sub> gives B, which on heating gives C. C when treated with Br<sub>2</sub> in the presence of KOH produces ethyl amine. Compound A is

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The order of reactivity of phenyl magnesium bromide (PhMgBr) with the following compounds:
questions.explanation:
The reactivity of the carbonyl group towards the nucleophilic addition reactions depend upon the magnitude of the positive charge on the carbonyl carbon atom (electronic factor) and also on the crowding around the carboxyl carbon atom in the transition state (steric factor). Both these factors predict the following order
I > II > III

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: What of the following compounds is most basic?
questions.explanation: In benzylamine the electron pair present on the nitrogen is not delocalised with the benzene ring.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Which of the following  is not a fat soluble vitamin?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin B complex is not a fat soluble vitamin.
It is a water soluble vitamin.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
Which of the statements about ''Denaturation'' given below are correct?

(1)  Denaturation of proteins causes loss of secondary and tertiary structures of the protein.
(2)  Denaturation leads to the conversion of double strand of DND into single strand.
(3)  Denaturation affects primary structure which gets distorted.
questions.explanation:
When the proteins are subjected to the
action of heat, mineral acids or alkali, the water
soluble form of globular protein changes to water
insoluble fibrous protein. This is called
denaturation of proteins. During denaturation
secondary and tertiary structures of protein
destroyed but primary structures remains intact.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: 200 mL of an aqueous solution of a protein contains its 1.26 g. The osmotic pressure of this solution at 300 K is found to be 2.57 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>$$-$$3</sup> bar. The molar mass of protein will be (R = 0.083 L bar mol<sup>$$-$$1</sup> K<sup>$$-$$1</sup>)
questions.explanation:
Osmotic pressure, $$\pi $$ = CRT

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$\pi $$ = $${n \over V}$$RT

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$\pi $$V = $${w \over M}$$RT

M = $${{wRT} \over {\pi V}}$$

= $${{1.26 \times 0.083 \times 300} \over {2.57 \times {{10}^{ - 3}} \times {{200} \over {1000}}}}$$

= $${{1.26 \times 0.083 \times 300} \over {2.57 \times {{10}^{ - 3}} \times 0.2}}$$

= 61038 g mol–1

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: A 0.1 molal aqueous solution of a weak acid is 30% ionized. If Kf for water is 1.86oC/m, the freezing point of the solution will be
questions.explanation:
We know that $$\Delta $$Tf = i × Kf × m

Here i is van’t Hoff’s factor.

i for weak acid is 1 + $$\alpha $$.

Here $$\alpha $$ is degree of dissociation i.e., 30/100 = 0.3

$$ \therefore $$ i = 1 + $$\alpha $$ = 1 + 0.3 = 1.3

$$ \therefore $$ Tf = i × Kf × m = 1.3 × 1.86 × 0.1 = 0.24

$$ \therefore $$ Freezing point = – 0.24

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
A solution contains Fe2+, Fe3+ and I$$-$$ ions. This solution was treated with iodine at 35oC. Eo for Fe3+/Fe2+ is + 0.77 V and Eo for I2/2I$$-$$ = 0.536 V.
The favourable redox reaction is

options.content: I<sub>2</sub> will be reduced to I<sup>$$-$$</sup>
there will be no redox reaction
I<sup>$$-$$</sup> will be oxidised to I<sub>2</sub>
Fe<sup>2+</sup> will be oxidised to Fe<sup>3+</sup>

questions.explanation:
Since the reduction potential of Fe3+/Fe2+ is greater than that of I2 /I– , Fe3+ will be reduced and I– will be oxidised.

2Fe3+ + 2I– $$ \to $$ 2Fe2+ + I2

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
The rate of the reaction :   2N2O5 $$ \to $$ 4NO2 + O2
can be written in three ways.

$${{ - d\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right]} \over {dt}} = k\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right]$$

$${{d\left[ {N{O_2}} \right]} \over {dt}} = k'\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right];\,\,$$ $${{d\left[ {{O_2}} \right]} \over {dt}} = k''\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right]$$

The relationship between k and k' and between k and k'' are
questions.explanation:
Rate of disappearance of reactants = Rate of appearance of products

$$ - {1 \over 2}$$$${{ - d\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right]} \over {dt}}$$ = $${1 \over 4}$$$${{d\left[ {N{O_2}} \right]} \over {dt}}$$ = $${{d\left[ {{O_2}} \right]} \over {dt}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${1 \over 2}$$$$k\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right]$$ = $${1 \over 4}$$$$k'\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right]$$ = $$k''\left[ {{N_2}{O_5}} \right]$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${k \over 2} = {{k'} \over 4} = k''$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $$k' = 2k ;  k'' = k/2$$

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The half-life of a substance in a certain enzyme-catalysed reaction is 138 s. The time required for the concentration of the substance to fall from 1.28 mg L<sup>$$-$$1</sup> to 0.04 mg L<sup>$$-$$1</sup> is
questions.explanation:
We know, $$N = {N_0}{\left( {{1 \over 2}} \right)^n}$$

Give N0(original amount) = 1.28 mg L–1

N (amount of substance left after time T) = 0.04 mg L–1

$$ \therefore $$ $${{0.04} \over {1.28}} = {\left( {{1 \over 2}} \right)^n}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${1 \over {32}} = {\left( {{1 \over 2}} \right)^n}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ n = 5

$$ \therefore $$ Time required = 5 × t1/2 = 5 × 138 = 690 s

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: The unit of rate constant for a zero order reaction is
questions.explanation:
Rate = K[A]0

Unit of k = mol L–1 sec–1

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.content: Pure sodium metal dissolves in liquid ammonia to give blue solution.
NaOH reacts with glass to give sodium silicate.
Aluminium reacts with excess NaOH to give Al(OH)<sub>3</sub>.

questions.explanation:
Al reacts with NaOH to give sodium metaaluminate.

2Al(s) + 2NaOH (aq) + 2H2O(l) $$ \to $$ 2NaAlO2 + 3H2

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content: Which of the following oxide is amphoteric?
questions.explanation:
SnO2 reacts with acid as well as base. So SnO2 is an amphoteric.

SnO2 + 4HCl $$ \to $$ SnCl2 + 2H2O

SnO2 + 2NaOH $$ \to $$ Na2SnO3 + H2O

CaO is basic in nature while SiO2 and CO2 are acidic in nature.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
The pairs of species of oxygen and their
magnetic behaviours are noted below. Which of
the following presents the correct description?
questions.explanation:
O2+ = KKσ2s2 σ*2s2 σ2pz2 (π2px2 = π2py2) (π*2px1)

O2 = KKσ2s2 σ*2s2 σ2pz2 (π2px2 = π2py2) (π*2px 1 = π*2py1)

O2 and O2+ contain unpaired electron in π* ABMO so paramagnetic.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
Which of the following carbonyls will have the
strongest C–O bond ?
questions.explanation:
Due to positive oxidation state of Mn back
donation in π* ABMO of CO is minimum
therefore C–O bond is strongest.

questions.subject: chemistry
questions.content:
Which of the following complex compounds will exhibit highest paramagnetic behaviour?
(At. No. Ti = 22, Cr = 24, Co = 27, Zn = 30)
questions.explanation:
[Cr(NH3)6]+3 [Ar] 3d3 4s0

three unpaired electron are present in t2g orbited

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The density of a material in CGS system of units is 4 g cm<sup>$$-$$3</sup>. In a system of units in which unit of length is 10 cm and unit of mass is 100 g, the value of density of material will be
questions.explanation:
In CGS system,

Density = 4$${g \over {c{m^3}}}$$

When unit of mass is 100g and unit of length is 10 cm, then

Density = x $${{100g} \over {{{\left( {10cm} \right)}^3}}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ 4$${g \over {c{m^3}}}$$ = x $${{100g} \over {{{\left( {10cm} \right)}^3}}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ x = 40 unit

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A particle covers half of its total distance with speed v<sub>1</sub> and the rest half distance with speed v<sub>2</sub>. Its average speed during the complete journey is
questions.explanation:
Let total distance = 2S

Let particle take t1 time to cover first S distance,

$$ \therefore $$ t1 = $${S \over {{v_1}}}$$

Let particle take t2 time to cover last S distance,

$$ \therefore $$ t2 = $${S \over {{v_2}}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ Average speed = $${{2S} \over {{S \over {{v_1}}} + {S \over {{v_2}}}}}$$ = $${{2{v_1}{v_2}} \over {{v_1} + {v_2}}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A projectile is fired at an angle of 45<sup>o</sup> with the horizontal. Elevation angle of the projectile at its highest point as seen from the point of projection, is
questions.explanation:
Let $$\phi $$ be elevation angle of the projectile at its highest point as seen from the point of projection O and $$\theta $$ be angle of projection with the horizontal.

From figure, tan$$\phi $$ = $${H \over {R/2}}$$      ....(1)

In case of projectile motion

Maximum height H = $${{{u^2}{{\sin }^2}\theta } \over {2g}}$$

Horizontal range, R = $${{{u^2}\sin \theta } \over g}$$

Substituting these values of H and R in (1), we get

$$\tan \phi = {{{{{u^2}{{\sin }^2}\theta } \over {2g}}} \over {{{{u^2}\sin 2\theta } \over {2g}}}}$$

$$\tan \phi = {{{{\sin }^2}\theta } \over {\sin 2\theta }} = {{{{\sin }^2}\theta } \over {2\sin \theta \cos \theta }}$$

= $${1 \over 2}\tan \theta $$

$$\tan \phi = {1 \over 2}\tan 45^\circ = {1 \over 2}$$

Here, $$\theta $$ = 45°

$$ \therefore $$ $$\tan \phi = {1 \over 2}\tan 45^\circ = {1 \over 2}$$    $$ \left(\because {\tan 45^\circ = 1} \right)$$

$$\phi = {\tan ^{ - 1}}\left( {{1 \over 2}} \right)$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A conveyor belt is moving at a constant speed of 2 ms<sup>$$-$$1</sup>. A box is gently dropped on it. The coefficient of friction between them is $$\mu $$ = 0.5. The distance that the box will move relativce to belt before coming to rest on it, taking g = 10 m s<sup>$$-$$2,</sup>, is
questions.explanation:
Force of friction, f = $$\mu $$mg

$$ \therefore $$ $$a = {f \over m} = {{\mu mg} \over m} = \mu g$$

$$ = 0.5 \times 10 = 5$$ ms-2

Using v2 – u2 = 2aS

02 – 22 = 2(–5) $$ \times $$ S

$$ \Rightarrow $$ S = 0.4 m

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A mass m moving horizontally (along the x-axis) with velocity $$v$$ collides and sticks to a mass of 3m moving vertically upwards (along the y-axis) with velocity 2$$v$$. The final velocity of the combination is
questions.explanation:
According to conservation of momentum, we get
$$mv\widehat i + \left( {3m} \right)2v\widehat j = \left( {m + 3m} \right)\overrightarrow {v'} $$

where $$\overrightarrow {v'} $$ is the final velocity after collision
$$\overrightarrow {v'} = {1 \over 4}v\widehat i + {6 \over 4}v\widehat j = {1 \over 4}v\widehat i + {3 \over 2}v\widehat j$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A small mass attached to a string rotates on a frictionless table top as shown. If the tension in the string is increased by pulling the string causing the radius of the circular motion to decrease by a factor of 2, the kinetic energy of the mass will
questions.explanation:
According to law of conservation of angular momentum

mvr = mv'r'

$$vr = v'\left( {{r \over 2}} \right)$$

$$v' = 2v$$    ...(i)

$$ \therefore $$ $${K \over {K'}} = {{{1 \over 2}m{v^2}} \over {{1 \over 2}mv{'^2}}} = {\left( {{v \over {v'}}} \right)^2}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {{K'} \over K} = {\left( {{{v'} \over v}} \right)^2} = {\left( 2 \right)^2}$$    (Using (i))

$$ \Rightarrow K' = 4K$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A particle of mass m is thrown upwards from the surface of the earth, with a velocity u. The mass and the radius of the earth are, respectively, M and R. G is gravitational constant and g is acceleration due to gravity on the surface of the earth. The minimum value of u so that the particle does not return back to earth, is
questions.explanation:
According to law of conservation of mechanical energy

$${1 \over 2}m{u^2} - {{GMm} \over R} = 0$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${u^2} = {{2GM} \over R}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $$u = \sqrt {{{2GM} \over R}} = \sqrt {2gR} $$   $$\left(\because {g = {{GM} \over {{R^2}}}} \right)$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A particle of mass M is situated at the centre of a spherical shell of same mass and radius a. The magnitude of the gravitational potential at a point sutuated at a/2 distance from the centre, will be :
questions.explanation:
Here, Mass of a particle = M
Mass of a spherical shell = M
Radius of a spherical shell = a
Let O be centre of a spherical shell.
Gravitational potential at point P due to particle at O is

$${V_1} = - {{GM} \over {a/2}}$$

Gravitational potential at point P due to spherical shell is

$${V_2} = - {{GM} \over a}$$

Hence, total gravitational potential at point P is V = V1 + V2

$$ = - {{GM} \over {a/2}} + \left( { - {{GM} \over a}} \right) = - {{2GM} \over a} - {{GM} \over a} = - {{3GM} \over a}$$

$$\left| V \right| = {{3GM} \over a}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A mass of diatomic gas $$(\gamma  = 1.4)$$ at a pressure of 2 atmospheres is compressed adiabatically so that its temperature rises from 27<sup>o</sup>C to 927<sup>o</sup>C. The pressure of the gas in the final state is
questions.explanation:
T1 = 273 + 27 = 300K

T2 = 273 + 927 = 1200K

For adiabatic process,

$${P^{1 - \gamma }}{T^\gamma }$$ = constant

$$ \Rightarrow {P_1}^{1 - \gamma }{T_1}^\gamma = {P_2}^{1 - \gamma }{T_2}^\gamma $$

$$ \Rightarrow {\left( {{{{P_2}} \over {{P_1}}}} \right)^{1 - \gamma }} = {\left( {{{{T_1}} \over {{T_2}}}} \right)^\gamma }$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\left( {{{{P_1}} \over {{T_2}}}} \right)^{1 - \gamma }} = {\left( {{{{T_2}} \over {{T_1}}}} \right)^\gamma }$$

$${\left( {{{{P_1}} \over {{P_2}}}} \right)^{1 - 1.4}} = {\left( {{{1200} \over {300}}} \right)^{1.4}}$$

$${\left( {{{{P_1}} \over {{P_2}}}} \right)^{ - 0.4}} = {\left( 4 \right)^{1.4}}$$

$${\left( {{{{P_2}} \over {{P_1}}}} \right)^{0.4}} = {4^{1.4}}$$

$${P_2} = {P_1}{4^{\left( {{{1.4} \over {0.4}}} \right)}} = {P_1}{4^{\left( {{7 \over 2}} \right)}}$$

= P1 (27) = 2 × 128 = 256 atm

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two particles are oscillating along two close parallel straight lines side by side, with the same frequency and amplitudes. They pass each other, moving in opposite directions when their displacement is half of the amplitude. The mean positions of the two particles lie on a straight line perpendicular to the paths of the two particles. The phase difference is
questions.explanation:
Equation of SHM is given by $$x = A\sin \left( {\omega t + \delta } \right)$$
$$\left( {\omega t + \delta } \right)$$ is called phase.

When x = $${A \over 2}$$, then

$$\sin \left( {\omega t + \delta } \right) = {1 \over 2}$$

$${ \Rightarrow \omega t + \delta = {\pi \over 6}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow {\phi _1} = {\pi \over 6}$$

For second particle,


$${\phi _2} = \pi - {\pi \over 6} = {{5\pi } \over 6}$$

$$ \therefore $$ $$\phi = {\phi _2} - {\phi _1}$$

$$ = {{4\pi } \over 6} = {{2\pi } \over 3}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Two identical piano wires, kept under the same tension T have a fundamental frequency of 600 Hz. The fractional increase in the tension of one of the wires which will lead to occurrence of 6 beats/s when both the wires oscillate together would be
questions.explanation:
As $$\upsilon = {1 \over {2L}}\sqrt {{T \over \mu }} $$

$$ \therefore {{\Delta \upsilon } \over \upsilon } = {1 \over 2}{{\Delta T} \over T}$$

$${{\Delta T} \over T} = 2{{\Delta \upsilon } \over \upsilon } = 2 \times {6 \over {600}} = 0.02$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The electric potential V at any point (x, y, z), all in metres in space is given by V = 4x<sup>2</sup> volt. The electric field at the point (1, 0, 2) in volt/meter, is
questions.explanation:
$$\overrightarrow E = - \overrightarrow \nabla V$$

where $$\overrightarrow \nabla = \widehat i{\partial \over {\partial x}} + \widehat j{\partial \over {\partial y}} + {\partial \over {\partial z}}$$

$$\overrightarrow E = - \left[ {\widehat i{{\partial V} \over {\partial x}} + \widehat j{{\partial V} \over {\partial y}} + \widehat k{{\partial V} \over {\partial z}}} \right]$$

Here, V = 4x2
$$ \therefore \overrightarrow E = - 8x\widehat i$$

The electric field at point (1, 0, 2) is

$${\overrightarrow E _{\left( {1,0,2} \right)}} = - 8\widehat iV{m^{ - 1}}$$

So electric field is along the negative X-axis.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Three charges, each +q, are placed at the corners of an isosceles triangle ABC of sides BC and AC, 2$$a$$. D and E are the mid points of BC and CA. The work done in taking a charge Q from D to E is
questions.explanation:
AC = BC

VD = VE

We have, W = Q (VE – VD)

$$ \Rightarrow $$ W = 0

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the circuit shown in the figure, if the potential at point A is taken to be zero, the potential at point B is
questions.explanation:
Current from D to C = 1A

$$ \therefore $$ VD – VC = 2 × 1 = 2V

VA = 0 $$ \therefore $$ VC = 1V,

$$ \therefore $$ VD – VC = 2

$$ \Rightarrow $$ VD – 1 = 2   $$ \therefore $$ VD = 3V

$$ \therefore $$ VD – VB = 2 $$ \therefore $$ 3 – VB = 2 $$ \therefore $$ VB = 1V

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Charge q is uniformly spread on a thin ring of radius R. The ring rotates about its axis with a uniform frequency $$f$$ Hz. The magnitude of magnetic induction at the center of the ring is
questions.explanation:
When the ring rotates about its axis with a uniform frequency f Hz, the current flowing in the ring is

I = $${q \over T}$$ = qf

Magnetic field at the centre of the ring is

B = $${{{\mu _0}I} \over {2R}}$$ = $${{{\mu _0}qf} \over {2R}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A galvanometer of resistance, G, is shunted by a resistance S ohm. To keep the main current in the circuit unchanged, the resistance to be put in series with the galvanometer is
questions.explanation:
To keep the main current in the circuit unchanged, the resistance of the galvanometer should be equal to the net resistance.

$$ \therefore $$ $$G = \left( {{{GS} \over {G + S}}} \right) + S'$$

$$ \Rightarrow G - {{GS} \over {G + S}} = S'$$

$$ \therefore S' = {{{G^2}} \over {G + S}}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A square loop, carrying a teady current $$I$$, is placed in a horizontal plane near a long straight conductor carrying a steady current $$I$$1 at a distance d from the conductor as shown in figure. The loop will experience

options.content: a net attractive force towards the conductor
a net repulsive force away from the conductor
a net torque acting upward perpendicular to the horizontal plane
a net torque acting downward normal to horizontal plane

questions.explanation: $${F_1} > {F_2}$$ as $$F \propto {1 \over d}$$, and $${F_3}$$ and $${F_4}$$ are equal and opposite. Hence, the net attraction force will be towards the conductor.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A short bar magnet of magnetic moment 0.4 J T<sup>$$-$$1</sup> is placed in a uniform magnetic field of 0.16 T. The magnet is in stable equilibrium when the potential energy is
questions.explanation:
When a bar magnet of magnetic moment is placed in a uniform magnetic field , its potential energy is

U = $$ - \overrightarrow M .\overrightarrow B = MB\cos \theta $$

For stable equilibrium, $$\theta $$ = 0o

U = –MB = – (0.4) (0.16) = – 0.064 J

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The r.m.s. value of potential difference V shown in the figure is
questions.explanation: V<sub>rms</sub> = $$\sqrt {{{{T \over 2}{{\left( {{V_0}} \right)}^2} + 0} \over T}}  = {{{V_0}} \over {\sqrt 2 }}$$

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A coil has resistance 30 ohm and inductive reactance 20 ohm at 50 Hz frequency. If an ac source, of 200 volt, 100 Hz, is connected across the coil, the current in the coil will be
questions.explanation:
Current flowing in the coil is

I = $${{200} \over Z} = {{200} \over {\sqrt {{R^2} + {{\left( {\omega L} \right)}^2}} }} = {{200} \over {\sqrt {{{\left( {30} \right)}^2} + {{\left( {40} \right)}^2}} }}$$ = 4 A

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A converging beam of rays is incident on a diverging lens. Having passed through the lens the rays intersect at a point 15 cm from the lens on the opposite side. If the lens is removed the point where the rays meet will move 5 cm closer to the lens. The focal length of the lens is
questions.explanation:
Here, v = +15 cm, u = +(15 – 5) = +10 cm

According to lens formula

$${1 \over v} - {1 \over u} = {1 \over f}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${1 \over {15}} - {1 \over {10}} = {1 \over f}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ f = -30 cm

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A thin prism of angle 15<sup>o</sup> made of glass of refractive index $$\mu $$<sub>1</sub> = 1.5 is combined with another prism of glass of refractive index $$\mu $$<sub>2</sub> = 1.75. The combination of the prisms produces dispersion without deviation. The angle of the second prism should be
questions.explanation:
For without deviation

$${A \over {A'}} = {{\mu ' - 1} \over {\mu - 1}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ $${{15} \over {A'}} = {{1.75 - 1} \over {1.50 - 1}}$$

$$ \Rightarrow $$ A' = 10o

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: The threshold frequency for a photosensitive metal is 3.3 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>14</sup> Hz. If light of frequency 8.2 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>14</sup> Hz is incident on this metal, the cut- off voltage for the photoelectron emission is nearly
questions.explanation:
K.E. = h$$\nu $$ – h$$\nu $$th = eV0 (V0 = cut off voltage)

$$ \Rightarrow $$ V0 = $${h \over e}\left( {8.2 \times {{10}^{14}} - 3.3 \times {{10}^{14}}} \right)$$

= $${{6.6 \times {{10}^{ - 34}}} \over {1.6 \times {{10}^{ - 19}}}}\left( {8.2 \times {{10}^{14}} - 3.3 \times {{10}^{14}}} \right)$$

$$ \approx $$ 2 V

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: An electron in the hydrogen atom jumps from excited state n to the ground state. The wavelength so emitted illuminates a photosensitive material having work function 2.75 eV. If the stopping potential of the photoelectron is 10 V, then the value of n is
questions.explanation:
KEmax = 10eV

$$\phi $$ = 2.75 eV

Total incident energy

E = $$\phi $$ + KEmax = 12.75 eV

$$ \therefore $$ Energy is released when electron jumps from the excited state n to the ground state.

$$ \therefore $$ E4 – E1 = {– 0.85 – (–13.6) ev} = 12.75eV

$$ \therefore $$ value of n = 4

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Out of the following which one is not a possible energy for a photon to be emitted by hydrogen atom according to Bohr's atomic model?
questions.explanation:
En = $$ - {{13.6} \over {{n^2}}}$$

$$ \therefore $$ E1 = –13.6 eV

E2 = –3.4 eV

E3 = –1.5 eV

E4 = –0.85 eV

$$ \therefore $$ E3 – E2 = –1.5 – (–3.4) = 1.9 eV

E4 – E3 = –0.85 – (–1.5) = 0.65 eV

Obviously, difference of 11.1 eV is not possible.

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: A Zener diode, having breakdown voltage equal to 15 V, is used in a voltage regulator circuit shown in figure. The current through the diode is
questions.explanation:
Voltage across 250 Ω resistance = 20 V – 15 V = 5 V

Now current through 250 $$\Omega $$ resistance: 5/250 = 20 mA

If voltage across load resistance 1 k$$\Omega $$ is 15 V, then

current through 1 kΩ is 15/1000 = 15 mA

The current through the zener diode is

= Current through 250 $$\Omega $$ resistance – Current through 1 k$$\Omega $$ resistance.

= 20 - 15

= 5 mA

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: In the following figure, the diodes which are forward biased, are
questions.explanation:
p-n junction is said to be forward biased
when p side is at high potential than n side. It is for
circuit (A) and (C).

questions.subject: physics
questions.content: Pure Si at 500 K has equal number of electron (n<sub>e</sub>) and hole (n<sub>h</sub>) concentrations of 1.5 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>16</sup> m<sup>$$-$$3</sup>. Doping by indium increases n<sub>h</sub> to 4.5 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>22</sup> m<sup>$$-$$3</sup>. The doped semiconductor is of

options.content: p-type having electron concentration n<sub>e</sub> = 5 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>9</sup> m<sup>$$-$$3</sup>
n-type with electron concentration n<sub>e</sub> = 5 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>22</sup> m<sup>$$-$$3</sup>
p-type with electron concentration n<sub>e</sub> = 2.5 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>10</sup> m<sup>$$-$$3</sup>
n-type with electron concentration n<sub>e</sub> = 2.5 $$ \times $$ 10<sup>23</sup> m<sup>$$-$$3</sup>

questions.explanation:
(ni)2 = ne × nh

(1.5 × 1016)2 = ne (4.5 × 1022)

So ne = 5 × 109

Now nh = 4.5 × 1022

$$ \Rightarrow $$ nh $$ >> $$ ne

Hence, semiconductor is p-type

and ne = 5 × 109 m–3

questions.subject: physics
questions.content:
A thermocouple of negligible resistance
produces an e.m.f. of 40 µV/ºC in the linear range
of temperature. A galvanometer of resistance 10
ohm whose sensitivity is 1 µA/division, is
employed with the thermocouple. The smallest
value of temperature difference that can be
detected by the system will be
questions.explanation:
For minimum deflection of 1 division required current = 1 µA

$$ \Rightarrow $$ Voltage required = IR = (1µA) (10) = 10 µV

$$ \therefore $$ 40 µV ≡ 1ºC

$$ \Rightarrow $$ 10 µV ≡ $${1 \over 4}$$ ºC = 0.25ºC
